messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Re: choosing parents/lives --was waldorf stuff an...
messages.msgSnippet: And I see it as an unschooling concept! lol Learn what you want, when you want to, and no one
messages.messageBody:
<<Quite a schoolish view of the reincarnational world.


Sandra>>

And I see it as an unschooling concept! lol

Learn what you want, when you want to, and no one will
tell you if that's right or wrong, it just is as you
want it, for your own growth.

Just like unschooling, actually!

With, depending on the spiritual beliefs you might
have, god, goddess, angels, oversoul, etc as your
facilitator and guide.

~Aimee

messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Re: choosing parents/lives --was waldorf stuff an...
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 8/11/04 4:50:46 PM, julie@bravewriter.com writes:
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 8/11/04 4:50:46 PM, julie@... writes:

<< Sandra, you probably realized that I didn't write what is below. I just
wanted to say so

because that view is the one that bugs me so much. >>

Sorry--I try to take the automatic who-wrote part off a lot of times even if
it WAS the author, because I really want it to be about the ideas and not
about the who. And because I usually ignore them myself, I don't notice them as
much as I should.

I'll try to be more careful.

Sandra

messages.subject: Re: choosing parents/lives --was waldorf stuff an...
messages.msgSnippet: Sandra, you probably realized that I didn t write what is below. I just wanted to say so because that view is the one that bugs me so much. I agree with what
messages.messageBody:
Sandra, you probably realized that I didn't write what is below. I just wanted to say so
because that view is the one that bugs me so much. I agree with what you wrote below it
wholeheartedly.

Julie B

--- In UnschoolingDiscussion@yahoogroups.com, SandraDodd@a... wrote:
> In a message dated 8/11/2004 3:08:45 PM Mountain Daylight Time,
> julie@b... writes:
> Many of us came from abusive backgrounds and would not be the people we
> are today if it were not for what we learned in our past. Of course, this is
> true for every
> person, whatever your past held for you...including beliefs, issues and
> strengths you carry
> within you from previous lives.
> ======================================
>
> When people survive divorce, the death of a child, a serious illness or
> accident, they learn from it. That doesn't suggest we should try to arrange for
> everyone ot have those experiences. A curriculum of experiences that each
> soul has to go through?
>
> Quite a schoolish view of the reincarnational world.
>
> Sandra
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Re: choosing parents/lives --was waldorf stuff an...
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 8/11/2004 3:08:45 PM Mountain Daylight Time, julie@bravewriter.com writes: Many of us came from abusive backgrounds and would not be the
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 8/11/2004 3:08:45 PM Mountain Daylight Time,
julie@... writes:
Many of us came from abusive backgrounds and would not be the people we
are today if it were not for what we learned in our past. Of course, this is
true for every
person, whatever your past held for you...including beliefs, issues and
strengths you carry
within you from previous lives.
======================================

When people survive divorce, the death of a child, a serious illness or
accident, they learn from it. That doesn't suggest we should try to arrange for
everyone ot have those experiences. A curriculum of experiences that each
soul has to go through?

Quite a schoolish view of the reincarnational world.

Sandra


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
